article.title: Colette
article.paragraph: Colette(IPA-frkɔ.lɛtlang) (Sidonie-Gabrielle Colette, 28 January 1873 3 August 1954) was a French novelist nominated for theNobel Prize in Literaturein 1948.http://www.nobelprize.org/nomination/archive/show_people.php?id=1883Her best known work, the novella,Gigi(1944), was the basis for theGigi (1958 film)filmandLerner and LoeweGigi (musical)stage productionof the same name. She was also aMime artistmime, an actress and a journalist.
article.heading: Life and career
Family and background
article.paragraph: Sidonie-Gabrielle Colette was born on 28 January 1873, to war hero and tax collector Jules-Joseph Colette and his wife Adle Eugnie Sidonie ("Sido"),neLandoy, in the village ofSaint-Sauveur-en-Puisayein thedepartementofYonne,Burgundy (French region)Burgundy. The family was initially well off, but by the time she was of school age poor financial management had substantially reduced her father's income and she attended a public school from the ages of 6 to 17 - this was, nevertheless, a fairly extensive education for a girl of the period.sfnTilburg200878sfnPortugesJouve199979
article.heading: Early years, 18931912
article.paragraph: In 1893 she marriedHenry Gauthier-Villars(18591931) or 'Willy', hisnom-de-plume,cite webhttp://www.wwd.com/eye/people/book-tells-story-of-colettes-france-7264395?srcBook Tells Story of Colette's FranceWWD27 December 20133 January 2014Koski, Lornaa well-known author and publisher, and her first four novelsthe four Claudine stories,Claudine l'cole(1900),Claudine Paris(1901),Claudine en menage(1902), andClaudine s'en va(1903)appeared under his name. They chart the coming of age of their heroine, Claudine, from an unconventional fifteen year old in a Burgundian village to the literary salons of turn-of-the-century Paris. (The four are published in English asClaudine at School,Claudine in Paris,Claudine Married, andClaudine and Annie). The story they tell is semi-autobiographical, but not entirelymost strikingly, Claudine, unlike Colette, is motherless.sfnSouthworth2004111-112sfnFlower201378

Willy, fourteen years older than his wife and one of the most notorious libertines in Paris, introduced Colette into avant-garde intellectual and artistic circles while betraying her sexually and encouraging her inlesbianismlesbianaffairs. It was he who chose the titillating subject-matter of the Claudine novels, "the secondary myth ofSappho...the girls' school or convent ruled by a seductive female teacher"(Ladimer, p. 53). Nevertheless, Colette later said that she would never have become a writer if not for Willy.sfnLadimer199951-53sfnPortugesJouve199479

Colette and Willy separated in 1906, although it was not until 1910 that the divorce became final. She had no access to the sizable earnings of the Claudine books - the copyright belonged to Willy - and until 1912 she followed a stage career in music halls across France, sometimes playing Claudine in sketches from her own novels, earning barely enough to survive and often hungry and unwell. This period of her life is recalled inLa Vagabonde(1910), which deals with women's independence in a male society - a theme to which she would regularly return in future works. During these years she embarked on a series of relationships with other women, notably withCharles de Morny, Duke of MornyMathilde de Morny, Marquise de Belbeuf ("Missy"), with whom she sometimes shared the stage. On January 3, 1907, an onstage kiss between Missy and Colette in a pantomime entitledRve d'gyptecaused a near-riot, and as a result they were no longer able to live together openly, although their relationship continued for another five years.sfnFlower2013145sfnRodriguez2002131sfnBenstock198648-49

In 1912 she marriedHenri de Jouvenel, the editor ofLe Matin (France)Le Matin. A daughter,Colette de Jouvenel, nick-namedBel-Gazou, was born in 1913. During the war she devoted herself to journalism, but marriage allowed her to devote her time to writing.sfnFlower2013145sfnPortugesJouves199480sfnCottrell1991262
article.heading: Writing career, 19201954
article.paragraph: In 1920 Colette publishedChri (novel)Chri, portraying love between an older woman and a much younger man. Chri is the lover of La, a wealthycourtesan; La is devastated when Chri marries a girl his own age, and delighted when he returns to her, but after one final night together she sends him away again.sfnJouves1987109-111

The marriage to Jouvenel ended in divorce in 1924, partly due to Jouvenel's infidelities and partly to Colette's own affair with her sixteen year old stepson,Bertrand de Jouvenel. In 1925 she met Maurice Goudeket, who became her final husband (the couple stayed together until her death).sfnFlower2013145sfnPortugesJouves199480

Already an established writer (The Vagabondhad received three votes for the prestigiousPrix Goncourt), the decades of the 1920s and 1930s were Colette's most productive and innovative period.sfnLadimer199957Set mostly in Burgundy or Paris during theBelle poque, her work treated married life, sexuality, and the problems of a woman's struggle for independence. It was frequently quasi-autobiographical:Chri (novel)Chri(1920) andLe Bl en herbe(1923) both deal with love between an aging woman and a very young man, a situation reflecting her relationship with Bertrand de Jouvenel and even Goudeket, who was sixteen years her junior.sfnPortugesJouves199480sfnFlower2013145La Naissance du Jour(1928) is her explicit criticism of the conventional lives of women, expressed in a meditation on age and the renunciation of love through the character of her mother, Sido.sfnLadimer199957-58

By this period Colette was frequently acclaimed as France's greatest woman writer. "It ... has no plot, and yet tells of three lives all that should be known", wroteJanet FlannerofSido. "Once again, and at greater length than usual, she has been hailed for her genius, humanities and perfect prose by those literary journals which years ago ... lifted nothing at all in her direction except the finger of scorn."sfnFlanner197270
article.heading: Last years, 19401954
article.paragraph: Colette was 67 years old at thefall of France, and remained in Paris, in her apartment in thePalais Royal. Her husband Maurice Goudeket, a Jew, was arrested by the Gestapo in December 1941, and although he was released after a few months through the intervention of the French wife of the German ambassador, Colette lived through the rest of the war years with the anxiety of a possible second arrest.sfnPortugesJouve199480-81sfnRosbottom2014unpaginatedDuring the Occupation she produced two volumes of memoirs,Journal rebours(1941) andDe ma fentre(1942 - the two issued in English in 1975 asLooking Backwards).sfnFlower2013145

In 1944 she published what became perhaps her most famous work,Gigi, telling the story of sixteen year old Gilberte ("Gigi") Alvar. Born into a family ofDemimondedemimondaines, Gigi is being trained as a courtesan to captivate a wealthy lover, but breaks with tradition by marrying him instead.sfnSnodgrass2015bunpaginatedIn 1949 it was made into a French film starringDanile DelormeandGaby Morlay, then in 1951 adapted for the stage with the then-unknownAudrey Hepburnin the title role, picked by Colette personally; the 1958 Hollywood musical, starringLeslie CaronandLouis Jourdan, with a screenplay byAlan Jay Lernerand a score by Lerner andFrederick Loewe, won the Academy Award for Best Picture.

In the postwar years, she became a famous public figure, crippled by arthritis and cared for by Goudeket who supervised the preparation of her collected works, orOeuvres completes(1948-1950). She continued to write during these years, bringing outL'Etoile vesper(1944) andLe fanal bleu(1949), in which she reflected on the problems of a writer whose inspiration is primarily autobiographical. On her death on August 3, 1954, she was refused a religious funeral by the Catholic Church on account of her divorces, but was given a state funeral, the first French woman of letters to be granted this honour, and interred inPre-Lachaisecemetery.sfnPortugesJouve199480-81sfnRosbottom2014unpaginatedsfnFlower2013145
article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph: Image:perelachaise-Colette-p1000342.jpgthumbColette's tomb inPre Lachaise Cemetery.Colette was elected to theThe Royal Academies for Science and the Arts of BelgiumBelgian Royal Academy(1935), theEdmond Louis Antoine Huot de GoncourtAcadmie Goncourt(1945, and President in 1949), and a Chevalier (1920) and Grand Officer (1953) of theLgion d'honneur.sfnCottrell1991262

Initially considered a limited if talented novelist (despite the outspoken admiration in her lifetime of figures such asAndr GideandHenri de Montherlant), she has been increasingly recognised as an important voice in women's writing.sfnFlower2013145
Singer-songwriterRosanne Cashpaid tribute to the writer in the song, "The Summer I Read Colette", on her 1996 album10 Song Demo.
Truman Capotewrote a short story about her (1970) called "The White Rose".

The Colette Study Centre in France has numerous items related to Colette's life. Jane Gilmour, Ph.D, wroteColettes France: Her Lives, Her Loves(Hardie Grant Books), which is a book "about Colettes life through the places where she lived".

In 2014, SUNY Press publishedShipwrecked on a Traffic Island and Other Previously Untranslated Gems(translated by Zack Rogow and Rene Morel), a collection of sketches, mini-essays, radio talks, reminiscences, and journalistic pieces written by Colette. This was the first new work by Colette to appear in English in half a century.
